user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of fill_v1_v2_form:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
fill_v1_v2_form (const void *cls,
                 const char *mime,
                 struct Session *session,
                 struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  enum MHD_Result ret;
  char *reply;
  struct MHD_Response *response;
  size_t slen;
  (void) cls; /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  slen = strlen (SECOND_PAGE) + strlen (session->value_1)
         + strlen (session->value_2);
  reply = malloc (slen + 1);
  if (NULL == reply)
    return MHD_NO;
  snprintf (reply,
            slen + 1,
            SECOND_PAGE,
            session->value_1,
            session->value_2);
  /* return static form */
  response =
    MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback (slen,
                                                        (void *) reply,
                                                        &free);
  if (NULL == response)
  {
    free (reply);
    return MHD_NO;
  }
  add_session_cookie (session, response);
  if (MHD_YES !=
      MHD_add_response_header (response,
                               MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_ENCODING,
                               mime))
  {
    fprintf (stderr,
             "Failed to set content encoding header!\n");
  }
  ret = MHD_queue_response (connection,
                            MHD_HTTP_OK,
                            response);
  MHD_destroy_response (response);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no occurrences of compiler language extensions in the provided code. Specifically:
- There are no GCC/Clang/other-compiler extension tokens or builtins such as __attribute__, __extension__, __typeof__, __asm__, __inline__ (non-standard form), __builtin_*, or labels-as-values (&&label).
- There are no statement expressions ({ ... }) used as expressions, no nested functions, and no use of inline assembly.
- No nonstandard integer types or compiler-specific pragmas are present.
- The casts (void *)reply and the use of &free to pass a function pointer are standard C and not compiler extensions.
- All control-flow and declarations use standard C syntax (static function, enum type, pointer parameters, standard library calls: malloc, snprintf, strlen, free).

Therefore nothing in this fragment meets the criterion “explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.” If you want, I can re-check if any referenced macros/externals (e.g., SECOND_PAGE or the MHD_* APIs) are implemented using compiler extensions elsewhere in the project; those would need to be inspected in their definitions.
